s.text: Compare that with Windows 98: $199 for a full setup, $89 for an upgrade, or bundled for "free" as part of nearly every non-Macintosh computer.
It looked like a pale and wan version of Microsoft Windows--with tiny, little crude buttons--even though it predates Windows.
Prove that a computer ignoramus can install the operating system on a computer that was running Windows 98.

My officemate suggested that maybe all I needed to do was adjust my proxy settings in Netscape and not my SOCKS.
Cracking Mastering Linux open, I was struck by its similarity to motorcycle manuals.
With Microsoft Helpdesk assistance I figured out that my CD-ROM drive was probably connected to my sound card and not to the IDE port, and thus was foiling Linux.
I informed him of my CD-ROM/sound card suspicions, and he pried open my computer's metal box and started gabbing about 40-pin connections.
Just the sight of Mastering Linux induced the stomach-churning sense of dread that my sixth-grade math textbook once gave me: "I don't get this.
The Linux that came with Mastering Linux was never going to communicate with my CD-ROM drive, and I began to lose all enthusiasm for the project.

I told it to go to my CD-ROM drive where the Linux CD resided--and promptly hit a brick wall.
Compare that with Windows 98: $199 for a full setup, $89 for an upgrade, or bundled for "free" as part of nearly every non-Macintosh computer.
I also didn't attach my Linux machine to the company network--because I couldn't find easy instructions in my books, and further consultations with the Helpdesk would have been cheating.
I'm fairly certain that setting up a printer is easy, but I'm taking the word of Linux experts on this.
Even though Linux is supposed to demolish Microsoft, the Microsoft Helpdesk, which provides computer assistance to its employees, was surprisingly helpful.

In 15 or so calls to the Helpdesk, I encountered only one person who sounded annoyed rather than curious (and even, dare I say, gleeful) at the fact I was firing up Linux.
